ayahs.text:
This verse begins with a rhetorical question: "Have you not seen how your Lord dealt with the companions of the elephant?" This opening draws attention to a well-known historical event that occurred in the year of Prophet Muhammad's birth, making it a significant marker in Arabian history. The question format is used to emphasize the remarkable nature of Allah's intervention and the clear signs of His power.

The "companions of the elephant" refers to Abrahah and his army who came from Yemen with the intention of destroying the Kaaba in Mecca. The use of the term "companions" indicates that the elephant was not merely a tool but a central part of their military strategy, highlighting the formidable nature of their expedition and making Allah's victory over them even more remarkable.

This verse asks: "Did He not make their plot go astray?" The question emphasizes how Allah rendered all their schemes ineffective and futile. Abrahah's expedition had multiple objectives beyond just destroying the Kaaba - he also aimed to spread Christianity in Arabia and seize control of the trade that flowed between the Eastern lands and Byzantine territories through the Arabs.

The word "plot" (kayd) encompasses all their strategic planning, military preparation, and political objectives. Despite their careful planning and seemingly overwhelming military advantage, Allah caused all their efforts to fail completely. This demonstrates that no matter how powerful human schemes may appear, they cannot succeed against divine will and protection of what Allah has sanctified.

This verse describes the means of their destruction: "And He sent against them birds in flocks." The verse reveals how Allah used the most humble of His creatures - small birds - to defeat what appeared to be an invincible army. These birds came in organized flocks, swooping down from the direction of the sea in coordinated attacks that overwhelmed the enemy forces.

The choice of small birds as the instrument of destruction emphasizes Allah's absolute power - He did not need to use extraordinary forces or supernatural powers. Instead, He demonstrated that even the smallest and seemingly weakest of His creatures can accomplish what He wills when acting under His command. This serves as a powerful reminder that divine power operates beyond human calculations of strength and weakness.

This verse describes the method of attack: "Striking them with stones of baked clay." The term 'sijjil' is derived from the Persian compound 'sang-i-gil,' where 'sang' means stone and 'gil' means clay, referring to stones made of clay. These are small pebbles that form when light rain falls on sandy ground and subsequently hardens under intense continuous sunlight, creating hard pellets from the mixture of sand and wet earth.

Each bird carried three small stones - one in its beak and two in its claws. The precision and coordination of this attack demonstrate divine orchestration rather than random natural phenomenon. Allah did not require the use of any extraordinary force to destroy Abrahah's mighty army; instead, He sent flocks of small birds that, within moments of their stone bombardment, completely devastated the forces that had seemed so formidable.

This final verse describes the complete destruction: "And He made them like eaten straw." The comparison to chewed and discarded straw emphasizes the utter devastation and humiliation that befell this once-mighty army. Just as straw that has been consumed by animals is left scattered, broken, and worthless, so too was the fate of those who dared to attack Allah's sacred house.

This imagery powerfully conveys not just physical destruction but also the complete failure and futility of their mission. From a formidable military expedition with elephants and advanced weaponry, they were reduced to something as insignificant and discarded as animal fodder. This serves as a timeless lesson about the fate that awaits those who oppose divine authority and attempt to destroy what Allah has made sacred.
